page.title: A Definition for Academic Language
page.contents:
Language used in the classroom and workplace

  • The language of text
  • The language of assessments
  • The language of academic success
  • The language of power

Scarcella (2003)

Jeff Zwiers (2014), a leading expert in this area, defines academic language as "... the set of words, grammar, and discourse strategies used to describe complex ideas, higher-order thinking processes, and abstract concepts" (p. 22).

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT2_0020.mp3

Audio transcript


What is academic language? Academic language is found in academic texts and classroom settings, but it is so much more and is essential for adult ELLs to advocate for themselves and their families. It allows adult ELLs to gain access to opportunities at work and in their communities. It is the language we use to ask for a raise, when we want a police officer to issue a warning versus a ticket, or when we call a teacher about an issue with our child. We use this language to ask a landlord to make repairs or when we ask for a letter of recommendation from a colleague. We are doing adult ELLs a disservice when we ignore academic and professional language when choosing content, materials, and activities, even at beginning levels.

Now let’s compare everyday language to academic language.

page.title: Comparing Everyday Language to Academic Language
page.contents:
Everyday LanguageAcademic Language
  • Less complex
  • Accompanied by pictures, facial expressions, and gestures
  • Highly contextualized
  • Used to build relationships and get things done in less formal settings
  • Complex and abstract
  • Sophisticated vocabulary
  • Describes complex concepts, higher-order thinking skills, and abstraction


Zwiers (2014)

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT2_0030.mp3

Audio transcript


In speaking, everyday language is the language we use with family, friends, neighbors, or coworkers. We engage in everyday reading and writing tasks when we write grocery lists, read TV listings in the newspaper, send a text message to a friend, or write a note to a family member. Everyday language tends to be less complex and abstract compared with academic language, in both speech and writing. When conversing with someone in everyday language, we draw meaning from facial expressions and gestures. We also use slang and colloquial expressions, or reductions in our speech. We use everyday language to build relationships and get things done in our lives, such as ordering food at a restaurant, inviting a friend for dinner, or making a to-do list.

Academic language, on the other hand, tends to be more complex and abstract. Sometimes there are no visuals or context clues to help us understand meaning. If you review a competency-based textbook for adult ELLs, you will see a lot of everyday language in the tasks and texts. Before continuing, let’s see a vivid example of how we use different language in different situations. We also will see that academic language is not just the language of school.

page.title: We Use Different "Registers"
page.contents:
We use different registers in social settings versus academic or professional settings. A register is the way we adjust our language for a particular setting.

TASK: Look at the text message:

  • What is the relationship between the participants in this conversation?
  • How would you describe the register?
  • What are some features of that register?

page.title: Compare Your Answers to These
page.contents:
What is the relationship between the participants in this conversation?

A husband and wife

How would you describe the register?

They are using a very informal register.

What are some features of that register?

Colloquial language ("Hey, hon, ... Can you pick up?")
Speech reductions ("Gotta ...")

Now turn to a conversation between the husband and his boss.

page.title: A Professional Register
page.contents:
Now listen as James asks his boss for permission to leave.

  • How would you describe the register?
  • What are some features of that register?

Listen to Audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT2_0040.mp3

Audio transcript


[sound of typing]

James: Good morning, Ms. Foster. Do you have a moment?

Ms. Foster: Yes, James, just let me finish typing this e-mail. [sound of typing briefly] OK, what can I do for you?

James: Well, I just got a message that my daughter is sick. I need to pick her up and take her home. May I leave to do that?

Ms. Foster: Oh, I’m sorry to hear that she’s sick, but we have that important inspection at 2:00. Do you think you could return to the office by then?

James: Absolutely, I’ll be back by 2:00. I know how important that meeting is.

Ms. Foster: I hope she feels better, and see you this afternoon.

James: Yes, thank you. Good-bye.

Ms. Foster: See you at 2:00.

[sound of typing]

page.title: Now Compare Your Answers
page.contents:
How would you describe the register?

  • This time the register is more formal, which we could expect when speaking to a boss rather than texting a spouse.

What are some features of that register?

  • Using titles: "Ms. Foster" instead of a first name.
  • Using polite requests: "Do you have a moment?; May I leave to do that?"
  • Expressing expectations: "Do you think you could return by ...?"
  • Providing reasons and assurances: "Absolutely, I'll be back by 2:00."

page.title: Academic Language Is on a Continuum
page.contents:
Informal social conversations → Informal writing for social purposes → Informal writing or discussions in class or at work → Structured academic discussions in a school or the workplace → Formal presentations or edited writing

Ranney (2014)

Listen to audio

ELL_MOD1_UNIT2_0050.mp3

Audio transcript


In the first example, we saw very informal social communication, a text between family members; the second example was a more formal conversation that required a different register. Adult ELLs need to recognize these differences and employ different registers in different settings. They need to access increasingly complex texts as well. In this unit, we explore a systematic approach for analyzing the various registers and the level of language complexity that adult ELLs are likely to encounter at work, in further education or training, or in their communities. As you will see in this unit, academic language is on a continuum, and there is language that can be taught at all levels with learners with a variety of personal goals. If you completed Unit 1, you learned about the importance of increasing the rigor of instruction overall, and teaching academic language is just one part of that.

Continue for a brief reminder.

page.contents:

page.title: Meet Aadan From Somalia
page.contents:
For learners with limited prior formal schooling, we know it can take up to 10–15 years to develop academic language (Collier, 1989).

In Unit 1 of this module, we conducted a thorough analysis of Aadan's needs (analysis of Aadan's Needs) and identified the following needs:

  • Support his children's academic achievement.
  • Read complex work documents.
  • Earn a high school equivalency degree.

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT2_0060.mp3

Audio transcript


Perhaps the most compelling reason to work on academic language at all levels of instruction with adult ELLs is the real-world needs that learners face.

Aadan came to the United States 9 years ago as a refugee when he was 19 years old. Before that, he attended school for only 3 years in a refugee camp and has minimal literacy skills in his own language. He is married and has four school-aged children. He works as an attendant in a parking garage and attends English language classes three mornings per week. Because of his limited literacy skills, he has been placed in a beginning-level English class. At the same time, he has strong oral skills and is quite confident communicating with teachers and people in his community. His dream is to one day earn a high school equivalency diploma.

page.title: Aadan's Academic Language Needs
page.contents:
Learners with prior formal schooling in their first language now need practice with academic language skills in English.

To meet his dream of earning his high school equivalency degree, Aadan ultimately will need the following kinds of academic language:

  • Understand a text's scope and emerging meaning.
  • Determine the author's purpose, the intended audience, the tone of the text and author, and the text's general context.
  • Recognize and understand a work's thesis or theme.
  • Recognize text organization.
  • Summarize, paraphrase, and synthesize ideas.
  • State an opinion about what he has read.

Ongoing task: Record ideas for meeting Aadan's needs.

page.title: Meet Carlos from Mexico
page.contents:
In Unit 1 of this module, we conducted a thorough analysis of Carlos's needs (analysis of Carlos's needs) and identified the following personal and professional goals:

Personal/Professional Goals:

  • Return to a job as a mathematics teacher.
  • Move out of a lower wage job in manufacturing to a job in teaching.
  • Navigate the licensing processes for teachers in his state.

Academic Goals:

  • Move up to the advanced college bridge courses.
  • Enroll in courses needed for teacher licensure to become a mathematics teacher.
  • Prepare for the state teacher examinations.

Learners with prior formal schooling in their first language now need practice with academic language skills in English.

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT2_0080.mp3

Audio transcript


Carlos was a high school mathematics teacher is in his country. Currently, he works at a manufacturing company as he improves his English. He needs to work with his state to see if he meets licensure requirements. He almost certainly needs to take some education classes and pass the state teacher examinations, but he feels as if that is a long way off. Right now, he is in an high intermediate-level English language class in a large, urban adult education program. He has not scored high enough to be placed in the more advanced college bridge courses, but he thinks that is what he needs to get ahead.

page.title: Carlos’s Academic Language Needs
page.contents:
Carlos also needs practice with accessing academic texts, for example, determining an author's purpose, the intended audience, the tone of the text and author, and the text's general context; and recognizing text organization.

Carlos also needs to be developing the following strategies in his current English class:

  • Identify and use resources (print, electronic, and human) to learn about the state licensing procedures.
  • Use appropriate documentation processes for tasks (filing forms, writing e-mails).
  • Employ multiple strategies for organizing information (graphic organizers, outlining) to show the relationships between concepts.

Adult ELLs such as Carlos and Aadan need rigorous instruction in academic language in English.

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT2_0090.mp3

Audio transcript


In addition to the academic skills needed for accessing complex texts outlined for Aadan, Carlos needs to identify and use resources (print, electronic, and human) to learn about the state licensing procedures. No doubt he will need to use appropriate documentation processes for tasks (filing forms, writing e-mails) when pursuing further education or applying for licensure down the road. Be sure to see the LINCS ESL PRO PROJECT Module 2 on developing digital literacy. As he listens to lectures and reads academic materials, Carlos will need to employ multiple strategies for organizing information (graphic organizers, outlining) to show the relationships between concepts.

These vignettes highlight the importance of moving beyond basic skills with adult ELLs and including instruction that develops both academic and professional discourse. Let’s look at some other trends in adult education that underscore this on more rigorous instruction in ELA programs. Review Aadan’s vignette as well and note how activities or ideas could be used to support his development of academic language.

page.title: The Current Landscape of Adult Education in the United States
page.contents: Some current policies are supporting the shift to provide instruction that is more rigorous and academic at all levels of adult ELA programming. Read about the College and Career Readiness Standards for Adult Education (Pimentel, 2013) and the Workforce Investment and Opportunity Act (WIOA).

page.title: College and Career Readiness Standards for Adult Education
page.contents:
College and Career Readiness Standards for Adult Education* represent some key shifts in what curricula should include:

  • Shift 1, Complexity: Regular practice with complex text and its academic language
  • Shift 2, Evidence: Reading, writing, and speaking grounded in evidence from text, both literary and informational
  • Shift 3, Knowledge: Building knowledge through content-rich nonfiction

*The College and Career Readiness Standards (CCR) for Adult Education report presents a set of college and career readiness standards that reflect the content most relevant for preparing adult students for success in colleges, technical training programs, work, and citizenship—in the areas of English language arts/literacy and mathematics.

page.title: Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act (2013-2014)
page.contents:
The Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act (2013-2014) emphasizes the need to prepare all adults, including ELLs, to transition to further education, training, and employment in high-demand industries and occupations. Academic language is critical to prepare adult ELLs for the demands of work and further education.
